review.title: Possibilistic Answer Set Programming Revisited
review.abstract: Possibilistic answer set programming (PASP) extends answer set programming (ASP) by attaching to each rule a degree of certainty. While such an extension is important from an application point of view, existing semantics are not well-motivated, and do not always yield intuitive results. To develop a more suitable semantics, we first introduce a characterization of answer sets of classical ASP programs in terms of possibilistic logic where an ASP program specifies a set of constraints on possibility distributions. This characterization is then naturally generalized to define answer sets of PASP programs. We furthermore provide a syntactic counterpart, leading to a possibilistic generalization of the well-known Gelfond-Lifschitz reduct, and we show how our framework can readily be implemented using standard ASP solvers.

metadata.title: Possibilistic Answer Set Programming Revisited

sections.text: Possibilistic answer set programming (PASP) extends answer set programming (ASP) by adding a certain degree of security to each rule. Although such an extension is important from an application point of view, existing semantics are not well motivated and do not always produce intuitive results. To develop a more appropriate semantics, we first introduce a characterization of the response sets of classic ASP programs in the sense of a possible logic, in which an ASP program specifies a number of limitations in terms of possibility distributions. Naturally, this characterization is then generalized to define the response sets of PASP programs. In addition, we provide a syntactic counterpart that leads to a possible generalization of the well-known Gelfond-Lifschitz reduction, and we show how our framework can be easily implemented with standard ASP solvers.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions
sections.text: We have introduced a new characterization of classical response theories using possibility theory. Within this semantics, the rules of a classical normal program set a series of limitations of possibility distributions; the classical response theories then correspond to the least specific possibility distributions that meet these limitations and adhere to some general limitations; we then extended this idea to the possible ASP. The central observation was that the certainty of the conclusion of a rule should be given by the certainty that both the rule body and the rule itself are valid; and we have introduced a syntactical reduction that corresponds exactly to the proposed semantics for PASP. Finally, to demonstrate the applicability of our approach, we have shown how possible normal programs can be simulated by classical normal programs.
